question: Question 1 A surveyor measured the distance between two points on the plan drawn to a scale of [latex]1\ \text{cm} = 40\ \text{m}[/latex] and the result was 468 m. Later, it was discovered that the scale used was [latex]1\ \text{cm} = 20\ \text{m}[/latex]. The true distance between the points (in m) is ______ (round off to the nearest integer).
solution: [latex]\text{RF of wrong scale} = \frac{1}{20}[/latex] [latex]\text{RF of corrected scale} = \frac{1}{40}[/latex] [latex]\text{Measured length} = 468 , \text{m}[/latex] [latex]\text{Corrected length} = \left( \frac{(RF){\text{wrong scale}}}{(RF){\text{corrected scale}}} \right) \times \text{Measured length}[/latex] [latex]= \left( \frac{\frac{1}{20}}{\frac{1}{40}} \right) \times 468 = 936 , \text{m}[/latex]

question: Question 6 A child walks on a level surface from point [latex] P [/latex] to point [latex] \mathrm{Q} [/latex] at a bearing of [latex] 30^{\circ} [/latex], from point [latex] \mathrm{Q} [/latex] to point [latex] R [/latex] at a bearing of [latex] 90^{\circ} [/latex] and then directly returns to the starting point [latex] P [/latex] at a bearing of [latex] 240^{\circ} [/latex]. The straightline paths [latex] P Q [/latex] and [latex] Q R [/latex] are [latex] 4 m [/latex] each. Assuming that all bearings are measured from the magnetic north in degrees, the straight-line path length RP (in meters) is ____(rounded off to the nearest integer)
solution:
[latex]
\begin{array}{c|c|c}
Line & Length & Bearing \\
\hline
PQ &  4 \mathrm{~m}  &  30^{\circ}  \\
QR &  4 \mathrm{~m}  &  90^{\circ}  \\
RP &  \mathrm{L}  &  240^{\circ}  \\
\end{array}
[/latex] Closed traverse, [latex] \Sigma \mathrm{L}=0,4 \cos 30^{\circ}+4 \cos 90^{\circ}+\mathrm{L} \cos 240^{\circ}=0 [/latex] [latex] \therefore \mathrm{L}=6.928 \mathrm{~m} \approx 7 \mathrm{~m} [/latex]

question: Question 7 To finalize the direction of a survey, four surveyors set up a theodolite at a station [latex] \mathrm{P} [/latex] and performed all the temporary adjustments. From the station P, each of the surveyors observed the bearing to a tower located at station [latex] \mathrm{Q} [/latex] with the same instrument without shifting it. The bearing observed by the surveyors are [latex] 30^{\circ} 30^{\prime} 00^{\prime \prime}, 30^{\circ} 29^{\prime} 40^{\prime \prime}, 30^{\circ} 30^{\prime} 20^{\prime \prime} [/latex] and [latex] 30^{\circ} 31^{\prime} 20^{\prime \prime} [/latex]. Assuming that each measurement is taken with equal precision, the most probable value of the bearing is
solution: Most probable value with equal weightage [latex] =30^{\circ}\left[\frac{30^{\prime}+29^{\prime} 40^{\prime \prime}+30^{\prime} 20^{\prime \prime}+31^{\prime} 20^{\prime \prime}}{4}\right]=30^{\circ} 30^{\prime} 20^{\prime \prime} [/latex]

Question 11 A map is prepared with a scale of 1: 1000 and a contour interval of [latex]1 \mathrm{~m} [/latex]. If the distance between two adjacent contours on the map is [latex]10 \mathrm{~mm} [/latex], the slope of the ground between the adjacent contours is
solution:
Given, contour Interval [latex]=1 \mathrm{~m} [/latex] Distance between contour in map [latex]=10 \mathrm{~mm} [/latex] [latex]
\text { Map scale }=\frac{1}{1000}
 [/latex] [latex]\therefore \quad [/latex] Distance between contour [latex]=10 \times 1000 [/latex]

[latex]
=10,000 \mathrm{~mm}
 [/latex] [latex]\Rightarrow \quad [/latex] Gradient [latex]=\frac{\text { Contour Interval }}{\text { Distance between contour }} [/latex]

[latex]=\frac{1000 \mathrm{~mm}}{10,000 \mathrm{~mm}} [/latex]

[latex]=\frac{1}{10}=\frac{1}{10} \times 100=10 \% [/latex]

question: Question 12 Among the following statements relating the fundamental lines of a transit theodolite, which one is CORRECT
solution:
Line of collimation must be perpendicular to
horizontal axis.

options.A: The line of collimation must be perpendicular to the horizontal axis at its intersection with the vertical axis.
options.B: The axis of altitude level must be perpendicular to the line of collimation
options.C: The axis of plate level must lie in a plane parallel to the vertical axis.

Question 14 If the number of sides resulting in a closed traverse is increased from three to four, the sum of the interior angles increases by
solution: Sum of interior angles [latex] =(n-2) \times 180^{\circ}[/latex] So, sum of interior angles for 3 sides [latex] =(3-2) \times 180^{\circ}=180^{\circ}[/latex] Now, sum of interior angles for 4 sides [latex] =(4-2) \times 180^{\circ}=360^{\circ}[/latex] [latex]\therefore[/latex]  Increase in sum of interior angles [latex] =360^{\circ}-180^{\circ}=180^{\circ}[/latex]

Question 15 A delivery agent is at a location R. To deliver the order, she is instructed to travel to location [latex]P[/latex] along straight-line paths of [latex]\mathrm{RC}, \mathrm{CA}, \mathrm{AB}[/latex] and [latex]\mathrm{BP}[/latex] of [latex]5 \mathrm{~km}[/latex] each. The direction of each path is given in the table below as whole circle bearings. Assume that the latitude (L) and departure (D) of [latex]R[/latex] is [latex](0,0) \mathrm{km}[/latex]. What is the latitude and departure of [latex]P[/latex] (in km, rounded off to one decimal place)? [latex]

\begin{array}{|c|c|c|c|c|}
\hline
Paths & RC & CA & AB & BP \\
\hline
\begin{array}{c}\text {Directions} \\ \text {(in degrees)}\end{array} & 120 & 0 & 90 & 240 \\
\hline
\end{array}

[/latex]
solution:
Latitude of ' [latex]C[/latex] ' [latex]=-5 \sin 30^{\circ}=-2.5 \mathrm{Km}[/latex] Departure of ' [latex]C[/latex] ' [latex]=5 \cos 30^{\circ}=+4.33 \mathrm{Km}[/latex] Latitude of ' [latex]\mathrm{B}[/latex] ' [latex]=[/latex] Latitude of ' [latex]\mathrm{C}[/latex] ' [latex]+5 \mathrm{Km}[/latex]

[latex]=-2.5+5=+2.5 \mathrm{Km}[/latex] Departure of 'B' [latex]=[/latex] Departure of ' [latex]C[/latex] ' [latex]+5 \mathrm{Km}[/latex]

[latex]=+4.33+5=+9.33 \mathrm{Km}[/latex] Latitude of ' [latex]P[/latex] ' = Latitude of ' [latex]B[/latex] ' [latex]-5 \sin 30^{\circ}[/latex]

[latex]=+2.5-2.5=0[/latex] Departure of ' [latex]P[/latex] ' [latex]=[/latex] Departure of ' [latex]B[/latex] ' [latex]-5 \sin 30^{\circ}[/latex]

[latex]=9.33-4.33=+5 \mathrm{Km}[/latex] [latex]\therefore \quad \mathrm{L}=0.0, \quad \mathrm{D}=5.0[/latex]

Question 17 The magnetic bearing of the sun for a location at noon is [latex]183^{\circ} 30^{\prime}[/latex]. If the sun is exactly on the geographic meridian at noon, the magnetic declination of the location is ___
solution: At any place 12 O'clock sun will be exactly over the true meridian of that place. Declination [latex]=183^{\circ} 30^{\prime}-180^{\circ}=3^{\circ} 30^{\prime} \mathrm{W}[/latex] Magnetic declination will be [latex]3^{\circ} 30 \mathrm{~W}[/latex].

question:
Question 18 Trigonometric levelling was carried out from two stations [latex]P[/latex] and [latex]Q[/latex] to find the reduced level (R.L.) of the top of hillock, as shown in the table. The distance between stations [latex]P[/latex] and [latex]Q[/latex] is [latex] 55 \mathrm{~m}[/latex]. Assume stations [latex]P[/latex] and [latex]Q[/latex], and the hillock are in the same vertical plane. The R. L. of the top of the hillock  (in[latex]\mathrm{m}[/latex] ) is _____ (round off to three decimal places) [latex]
\begin{array}{|l|l|l|l|}
\hline Station &\begin{array}{c}\text{Vertical} \\ \text{angle of} \\
\text {the top of} \\ \text{hillock }\end{array} &\begin{array}{c}\text {Staff} \\ \text{reading} \\
\text {on} \\ \text{benchmark}\end{array} &\begin{array}{c}\text {R.L. of} \\
\text {benchmark}\end{array} \\
\hline P &18^{\circ} 45^{\prime} &2.340 \mathrm{~m} &100.000 \mathrm{~m} \\
\hline Q &12^{\circ} 45^{\prime} &1.660 \mathrm{~m}& \\
\hline
\end{array}
[/latex]
solution:
While taking reading from [latex]P[/latex], RL of hillock [latex]=H I_P+x \tan 18^{\circ} 45^{\prime}[/latex] [latex]=100+2.34+x \tan 18^{\circ} 45^{\prime}[/latex] While taking reading from [latex]Q[/latex]. [latex]\mathrm{RL}[/latex] of hillock [latex]=\mathrm{HI}_Q+(\mathrm{x}+55) \tan 12^{\circ} 45^{\prime}[/latex] [latex]=100+1.66+(x +55)\tan 12^{\circ} 45^{\prime}[/latex] Equating both, [latex]100+2.34+x \tan 18^{\circ} 45^{\prime}=100+1.66+(x +55)\tan 12^{\circ} 45^{\prime}[/latex] [latex]2.34+0.339 x=1.66+12.445+0.226 x[/latex] [latex]\therefore x=104.115[/latex] [latex]\quad \therefore \quad[/latex] RL of hillock [latex]
=100+2.34+104.115 \tan 18^{\circ} 45^{\prime}
[/latex] [latex]
=137.682
[/latex]

question: Question 19 A student is scanning his 10 inch [latex]\times [/latex] 10 inch certificate at 600 dots per inch (dpi) to convert it to raster. What is the percentage reduction in number of pixels if the same certificate is scanned at 300 dpi?
solution: DPI = Dots Per Inch, it should be noted that DPI is not dots per square inch. [latex]\%[/latex] reduction in number of pixels [latex]=\frac{10 \times 600 \times 10 \times 600-100 \times 300 \times 10 \times 300}{10 \times 600 \times 10 \times 600} \times 100[/latex] [latex]=\frac{600^{2}-300^{2}}{600^{2}} \times 100[/latex] [latex]=75 \%[/latex]

question: Question 20 The direct and reversed zenith angles observed by a theodolite are [latex]56^{\circ} 00^{\prime} 00^{\prime \prime}[/latex] and [latex]303^{\circ} 00^{\prime} 00^{\prime \prime}[/latex], respectively. What is the vertical collimation correction?
solution: In above example of both direct zenith angle and reversed zerwith angle are smaller than true value. The error [latex](\varepsilon)=\left[\frac{\left(\phi_{1}+\phi_{2}\right)-360}{2}\right][/latex] [latex]\therefore[/latex] here, error [latex]=\frac{\left(56^{\circ}+303^{\circ}\right)-360^{\circ}}{2}=-30^{\prime}[/latex] [latex]\therefore \quad[/latex] Correction [latex]=+30^{\prime}[/latex]

question:
Question 21 The error in measuring the radius of a 5 cm circular rod was 0.2%. If the
cross-sectional area of the rod was calculated using this measurement, then the
resulting absolute percentage error in the computed area is______.
(round off to two decimal places)
solution:
[latex]\begin{aligned}
r&=5 \\
e_r&=\frac{0.2}{100} \times 5=0.01cm  \\
A&=\pi r^2  \\
e_A&=2 \pi r.e_r  
\end{aligned} [/latex] Absolute perecentage error in computed area [latex]\begin{aligned}
&=\frac{e_A}{A} \times 100  \\
&=\frac{2 \pi r.e_r}{\pi r^2} \times 100\\
&=2 \times \left ( \frac{e_r}{r} \times 100 \right )\\
&=2 \times 0.2=0.4
\end{aligned} [/latex]

question: Question 24 A line between stations P and Q laid on a slope of 1 in 5 was measured as 350 m using a 50 m tape. The tape is known to be short by 0.1 m. The corrected horizontal length (in m) of the line PQ will be
solution:
Horizontal distance of line [latex]PQ=350 \cos \theta =\frac{350 \times 5}{\sqrt{26}}=343.20m[/latex] Tape is 0.1 m short. Nominal length of tape,[latex] l = 50 m[/latex] Actual length of tape, [latex]l' = 50 - 0.1 = 49.9 m[/latex] Corrected horizontal length of line PQ [latex]\begin{aligned}
&=\left ( \frac{l'}{l} \right ) \times 343.2\\
&=\left ( \frac{49.9}{50} \right )\times 343.2\\
&=342.517\simeq 342.52m
\end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 25 An aerial photograph is taken from a flight at a height of 3.5 km above mean
sea level, using a camera of focal length 152 mm. If the average ground
elevation is 460 m above mean sea level, then the scale of the photograph is
solution:
[latex]\begin{aligned}
H &=3.5Km=3500m\\ 
 f&=152mm \\ 
 h_{avg}&=460m \\ 
 Scale&=\frac{f}{H-h_{avg}} \\ 
 &= \frac{152 \times 10^{-3}}{3500-460}\\
&=\frac{1}{20000}
\end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 26 For a given traverse, latitudes and departures are calculated and it is found that sum of latitudes is equal to +2.1 m and the sum of departures is equal to -2.8 m. The length and bearing of the closing error, respectively, are
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} e_{L} &=+2.1 \mathrm{~m} \\ e_{D} &=-2.8 \mathrm{~m} \\ e &=\sqrt{e_{L}^{2}+e_{D}^{2}} \\ &=\sqrt{(2.1)^{2}+(2.8)^{2}}=3.5 \mathrm{~m} \\ \text { Bearing of closing error } &=\tan ^{-1}\left(\frac{e_{D}}{e_{L}}\right) \\ &=\tan ^{-1}\left(\frac{-2.8}{2.1}\right)=-53.13^{\circ} \\ &=53^{\circ} 7^{\prime} 48^{\prime \prime} \mathrm{NW} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 27 A horizontal angle [latex]\theta[/latex] is measured by four different surveyors multiple times and the values reported are given below. [latex]\begin{array}{|c|c|c|} \hline \text { Surveyor } & \text { Angle } \theta & \text { Number of observations } \\ \hline 1 & 36^{\circ} 30^{\prime} & 4 \\ \hline 2 & 36^{\circ} 00^{\prime} & 3 \\ \hline 3 & 35^{\circ} 30^{\prime} & 8 \\ \hline 4 & 36^{\circ} 30^{\prime} & 4 \\ \hline \end{array}[/latex] he most probable value of the angle [latex]\theta[/latex] ( in degree, round off to two decimal placesis ________
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \mathrm{MPV} &=\frac{\left(36^{\circ} 30^{\prime} \times 4\right)+\left(36^{\circ} \times 3\right)+\left(35^{\circ} 30^{\prime} \times 8\right)+\left(36^{\circ} 30^{\prime} \times 4\right)}{4+3+8+4} \\ &=36^{\circ} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 29 Traversing is carried out for a closed traverse PQRS. The internal angles at vertices P, Q, R and S are measured as [latex]92^{\circ} [/latex],[latex]68^{\circ} [/latex],[latex]123^{\circ} [/latex] and [latex]77^{\circ} [/latex], respectively. If fore bearing of line PQ is [latex]27^{\circ} [/latex], fore bearing of line RS (in degrees, in integer) is _________
solution: [latex]\begin{array}{l} Q=\left[\begin{array}{l} B B \text { of } P Q=27^{\circ}+180^{\circ}=207^{\circ} \\ F B \text { of } Q R=207^{\circ}-68^{\circ}=139^{\circ} \end{array}\right. \\ R=\left[\begin{array}{l} B B \text { of } Q R=139^{\circ}+180^{\circ}=319^{\circ} \\ F B \text { of } R S=319^{\circ}-123^{\circ}=196^{\circ} \end{array}\right. \end{array}[/latex] [latex]\begin{array}{l} Q=\left[\begin{array}{l} B B \text { of } P Q=27^{\circ}+180^{\circ}=207^{\circ} \\ F B \text { of } Q R=207^{\circ}+68^{\circ}=275^{\circ} \end{array}\right. \\ R=\left[\begin{array}{l} B B \text { of } Q R=275^{\circ}-180^{\circ}=95^{\circ} \\ F B \text { of } R S=95^{\circ}+123^{\circ}=218^{\circ} \end{array}\right. \end{array}[/latex]

Question 33 The diameter and height of a right circular cylinder are 3 cm and 4 cm, respectively.
The absolute error in each of these two measurements is 0.2 cm. The absolute error in
the computed volume (in [latex]cm^3[/latex], round off to three decimal places), is _______.
solution: Let diameter, x = 3 and height = y = 4 and error= [latex]\pm 0.2[/latex] [latex]\begin{aligned} V&= \pi\left ( \frac{x}{2} \right )^2y=\frac{\pi x^2 y}{4}\\ V&=f(x,y) \\ dV&= \left ( \frac{\partial V}{\partial x} \right )dx +\left ( \frac{\partial V}{\partial y} \right )dy\\ dV&= \left ( \frac{1}{2}\pi xy \right )dx +\left ( \frac{\pi x^2}{4} \right )dy\\ &= \frac{1}{2} \pi \times 3 \times 4 \times (0.2)+\frac{\pi}{4} \times (3)^2 \times (0.2)\\ &= 1.65 \pi\\ &=1.65 \times 3.14=5.18 \end{aligned}[/latex] i.e., absolute error = |5.18| = 5.18

Question 38 A camera with a focal length of 20 cm fitted in an aircraft is used for taking vertical aerial photographs of a terrain. The average elevation of the terrain is 1200 m above mean sea level (MSL). What is the height above MSL at which an aircraft must fly in order to get the aerial photographs at a scale of 1:8000?
solution: Given focal length = 20 cm as we know scale of vertical photograph [latex]=\frac{f}{H-h_{avg}}[/latex] its given as 1 : 8000 Hence, [latex]\begin{aligned} \frac{f}{H-h_{avg}} &=\frac{1}{8000} \\ \frac{20 cm}{(H-1200) \times 100cm}&=\frac{1}{8000} \\ \Rightarrow \;\;H &=2800m \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 39 Consider the hemi-spherical tank of radius 13 m as shown in the figure. What is the volume of water (in [latex]m^3[/latex]) when the depth of water at the centre of the tank is 6 m?
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \text{Volume of water}&=\frac{1}{3}\pi h^2(3r-h)\\ &=\frac{1}{3}\pi \times 6^2 \times (3 \times 13 -6)\\ &=396\pi \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 40 The data from a closed traverse survey PQRS (run in the clockwise direction) are given in the table The closing error for the traverse PQRS (in degrees) is ___
solution:
Assuming it as anticlockwise traverse. Mathematically sum of interior angle for a closed traverse
[latex]=(2n-4)\times 90 = (2 \times 4 -4) \times 90 = 360^{\circ}[/latex] Given sum of interior angles,
[latex]= 88 + 92 + 94 + 89 = 363^{\circ}[/latex] Then error in interior angle [latex]= 363 - 360 = 3^{\circ}[/latex] Note: In this question as per clockwise traverse included angle should be taken as exterior angle. But if we take exterior angle then we get all interior angles more than
[latex]180^{\circ}[/latex].

question: Question 41 A staff is placed on a benchmark (BM) of reduced level (RL) 100.000 m and a theodolite is placed at a horizontal distance of 50 m from the BM to measure the vertical angles. The measured vertical angles from the horizontal at the staff readings of 0.400 m and 2.400 m are found to be the same. Taking the height of the instrument as 1.400m, the RL (in m) of the theodolite station is _____
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} x&=50 \tan \alpha \\ 2-x&=50 \tan \alpha \\ \therefore \;\;x&=2-x \\ 2x&=2 \\ x&=1m \end{aligned}[/latex] R.L of theodolite station (P): 100 + 1.4 - 0.1 - 0.4 = 100 m

question: Question 42 The interior angles of four triangles are given below: Which of the triangles are ill-conditioned and should be avoided in Triangulation surveys?
solution: For an ill conditioned traingle in triangulation survey, any angle can be less than [latex]30^{\circ}[/latex], and can be greater than [latex]120^{\circ}[/latex]. For traingles Q and S, the above condition is valid.

question: Question 43 An aerial photograph of a terrain having an average elevation of 1400 m is taken at a scale of 1:7500. The focal length of the camera is 15 cm. The altitude of the flight above mean sea level (in m, up to one decimal place) is ______
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} h &=1400 \mathrm{m} \\ \text { Scale } &=1: 7500 \\ f &=15 \mathrm{cm} \\ \text { Scale } &=\frac{f}{H-h} \\ \Rightarrow\quad \frac{1}{7500} &=\frac{15 \times 10^{-2}}{H-1400} \\ \Rightarrow\quad H &=2525 \mathrm{m} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 44 A level instrument at a height of 1.320 m has been placed at a station having a Reduced Level (RL) of 112.565 m. The instrument reads -2.835 m on a levelling staff held at the bottom of a bridge deck. The RL (in m) of the bottom of the bridge deck is
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} &\text { RL of bottom of bridge deck }\\ &=112.565+1.320+(2.835)\\ &=116.720 \mathrm{m} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 45 A square area (on the surface of the earth) with side 100 m and uniform height, appears as 1 [latex]cm^{2}[/latex] on a vertical aerial photograph. The topographic map shows that a contour of 650 m passes through the area. If focal length of the camera lens is 150 mm, the height from which the aerial photograph was taken, is
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} A&=100 \times 100 \mathrm{m}^{2}\\ \text { Area on photo, }\\ a &=1 \mathrm{cm}^{2} \\ \text { Scale } \quad 1 \mathrm{cm} &=100 \mathrm{m} \\ f &=150 \mathrm{mm} \\ h &=650 \mathrm{m} \\ \text { Scale } \quad &=\frac{1}{100}=\frac{1}{100 \times 10^{2}}\\ &=\frac{1}{10000}=\frac{f}{H-h}\\ \Rightarrow \quad \frac{1}{10000}&=\frac{150 \times 10^{-3}}{H-650} \\ \Rightarrow \quad H&=2150 \mathrm{m} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 46 The following details refer to a closed traverse: The length and direction (whole circle bearing) of closure, respectively are
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \text { Latitude }_{P Q} &=L_{P Q}=-437 \mathrm{m} \\ L_{S P} &=-83 \mathrm{m} \\ L_{O R} &=+101 \mathrm{m}\\ L_{R S} &=+419 \mathrm{m} \\ \Sigma \text { Latitudes } &=-437-83+101+419 \\ &=0 \mathrm{m} \\ \text { Departure }_{P O} &=D_{P O}=+173 \mathrm{m} \\ D_{O R} &=+558 \mathrm{m} \\ D_{8 S} &=-96 \mathrm{m} \\ D_{S P} &=-634 \mathrm{m} \end{aligned}[/latex] [latex] \Sigma[/latex] Departures =1 m For closure of traverse [latex] \Sigma[/latex] Latitude =0 [latex] \Sigma [/latex] Departure =0 Then, Departure of closure =-1 m, Latitude of closure =0 So the length and direction (whole circle bearing of closure is 1m and [latex]270^{\circ}[/latex] respectively.

question: Question 47 An observer standing on the deck of a ship just sees the top of a lighthouse. The top of the lighthouse is 40 m above the sea level and the height of the observer's eye is 5 m above the sea level. The distance (in km, up to one decimal place) of the observer form the lighthouse is____
solution: Distance of observer trom the lighthouse, [latex] \begin{aligned} d &=d_{1}+d_{2} \\ &=3.865\left(\sqrt{h_{1}}+\sqrt{h_{0}}\right) \\ &=3.865(\sqrt{5}+\sqrt{40}) \\ &=33.0012 \mathrm{km} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 48 Two towers A and B, standing vertically on a horizontal ground, appear in a vertical aerial
photograph as shown in the figure. The length of the image of the tower A on the photograph is1.5 cm and of the tower B is 2.0
cm. The distance of the top the tower A (as shown by the arrowhead) is 4.0 cm and the
distance of the top of the tower B is 6.0 cm, as measured form the principal point p of the
photograph. If the height of the tower B is 80 m, the height (in meters) of the tower A is_____
solution: For Tower A: Reliet displacement, [latex] \begin{array}{l} d_{A}=1.5 \mathrm{cm} \\ r_{A}=4 \mathrm{cm} \\ h_{A}=? \end{array}[/latex] For Tower B: Relier displacement. [latex] \begin{array}{l} d_{B}=2.0 \mathrm{cm} \\ r_{B}=6 \mathrm{cm} \\ h_{B}=80\mathrm{m} \end{array}[/latex] Reliet displacement. [latex] \begin{aligned} D&=\frac{h.r}{\left(H-h_{\text{avg}} \right )}\\ \text{For A:}d_{A}&=\frac{h_{A}.r_{A}}{\left(H-h_{\text{avg}} \right )}\\ 1.5&=\frac{h_{A}\times 4}{240}\\ h_{A}&=90m\\ \text{For B: }d_{B}&=\frac{h_{B}.r_{B}}{\left(H-h_{\text{avg}} \right )}\\ \Rightarrow \quad 2&=\frac{80\times 6}{\left(H-h_{\text{avg}} \right )}\\ \Rightarrow \left(H-h_{\text{avg}} \right )&=240m \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 53 The accuracy of an Electronic Distance Measuring Instrument (EDMI) is specified as [latex]\pm[/latex]( a mm + b ppm). Which one of the following statements is correct?
solution:
Accuracy of EDMI is generally stated in terms 
of constant instruments error and a measuring 
error proportional to the distance being measured: [latex]\pm [/latex](a mm + b ppm). The first part indicates a 
constant instrument error that is independent of 
the length of the line measured. The second 
component is the distance related error.

options.A: Both a and b remain constant, irrespective of the distance being measured.
options.B: a remains constant and b varies in proportion to the distance being measured.
options.C: a varies in proportion to the distance being measured and b remains constant.
options.D: Both a and b vary in proportion to the distance being measured.

question: Question 54 A tall tower was photographed from an elevation of 700 m above the datum. The radial distances of the top and bottom of the tower from the principal points are 112.50 mm and 82.40 mm, respectively. If the bottom of the tower is at an elevation 250 m above the datum, then the height (expressed in m) of the tower is _____.
solution: Given [latex] H=700 \mathrm{m}_{1} h_{\text {avg }}=250[/latex] Relief distance, [latex] \begin{aligned} d&=f_{1}=1 \\ &=112.5-82.40=30.1 \mathrm{mm}\\ \therefore\quad d&=\frac{h_{1}}{H=h_{a v}}\\ &[\text{where his height of tower}]\\ \Rightarrow \quad 30.1&=\frac{h \times 112.5}{100=250} \\ \therefore \quad h&=120.4 \mathrm{mm} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 58 The vertical angles subtended by the top of a tower T at two instrument stations set up at P and Q, are shown in the figure. The two stations are in line with the tower and spaced at a distance of 60m. Readings taken from these two stations on a leveling staff placed at the benchmark (BM = 450.000 m) are also shown in the figure. The reduced level of the top of the tower T (expressed in m) is _____ .
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \ln \Delta B E T \\ \tan 16.5^{\circ}&=\frac{x}{y}\\ \Rightarrow \quad y&=3.3759 x &\ldots(i)\\ In \triangle A O T \\ \tan 10.5&=\frac{x+2}{60+y}&\ldots(ii) \end{aligned}[/latex] Put value of y in eq. (ii) [latex] \begin{aligned} 0.1853&=\frac{x+2}{60+3.3759 x} \\ 11.1203+&0.6255 x=x+2 \\ x=& 24.3588 \mathrm{m} \end{aligned}[/latex] So, the reduced level of tower [latex] \begin{aligned} T&=450.000+2.555+24.358\\ &=476.911 \mathrm{m} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 59 The staff reading taken on a workshop floor using a level is 0.645 m. The inverted staff reading taken to the bottom of a beam is 2.960 m. The reduced level of the floor is 40.500 m. The reduced level (expressed in m) of the bottom of the beam is
solution: Height of instrument, HI A.L. of floor + stall reading from floor [latex] \begin{array}{l} =40.500+0.645 \\ =41.145 \mathrm{m} \end{array}[/latex] R.L. of bottom of beam =H / 4 inverted staff reading taken from bottom of beam [latex] \begin{array}{l} =41.145+2.800 \\ =44.105 \mathrm{m} \end{array}[/latex]

question: Question 62 Two pegs A and B were fixed on opposite banks of a 50m wide river. The level was set up at A and the staff readings on Pegs A and B were observed as 1.350 m and 1.550 m, respectively. Thereafter the instrument was shifted and set up at B. The staff readings on Pegs B and A were observed as 0.750 m and 0.550 m, respectively. If the R.L. of Peg A is 100.200 m, the R.L. (in m) of Peg B is _____
solution: Staff readings shows that station B is below station A [latex] \begin{aligned} a_{1} &=1.350 \\ a_{2} &=0.550 \\ b_{1} &=1.550 \\ b_{2} &=0.750 \\ h_{18} &=\frac{\left(b_{1}-a_{1}\right)+\left(b_{2}-a_{2}\right)}{2} \\ &=\frac{(1.550-1.350)+(0.750-0.550)}{2} \\ &=0.200\\ \text{RL of }B&=\text{RL of A}-0.200 \\ &=100.200-0.200 \\ &=100.000 \mathrm{m} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 63 The bearings of two inaccessible stations, [latex]S_{1}[/latex] (Easting 500 m, Northing 500 m) and [latex]S_{2}[/latex] (Easting 600 m, Northing450 m) from a station [latex]S_{3}[/latex] were observed as [latex]225^{\circ}[/latex] and [latex]153^{\circ}{26}'[/latex] respectively. The independent Easting (in m) of station [latex]S_{3}[/latex] is:
solution: [latex]Let S_{1} S_{3}=l_{1}\text{ and }S_{2} S_{3}=l_{2} [/latex] Northing of [latex]\mathrm{S}_{3}: [/latex] [latex] \begin{aligned} &500+l_{1} \cos 45^{\circ}=450+l_{2} \cos 26^{\circ} 34^{\prime} \\ &l_{1} \cos 45^{\circ}-l_{2} \cos 26^{\circ} 34^{\prime}=-50 &\ldots(i) \end{aligned}[/latex] Easting of [latex]\mathrm{S}_{3}: [/latex] [latex] \begin{aligned} 500+l_{1} \sin 45^{\circ}=600-l_{2} \sin 26^{\circ} 34^{\prime} \\ l_{1} \sin 45^{\circ}+l_{2} \sin 26^{\circ} 34^{\prime}=100 &\ldots(ii) \end{aligned}[/latex] Solving eq. (i) and eq. (ii), [latex] \begin{aligned} l_{1}&=70.707 \\ l_{2}&=111.802 \end{aligned}[/latex] [latex] \therefore \quad[/latex] Easting of [latex]S_{3}=500+70.707 \sin 45^{\circ} [/latex] [latex] =550 \mathrm{m}[/latex]

question: Question 64 The combined correction due to curvature and refraction (in m) for distance of 1 km on the surface of Earth is
solution: Correction due to curvature, [latex] C_{c}=-0.0785 d^{2}[/latex] Correction due to refraction, [latex] C_{f}=+0.0112 d^{2}[/latex] [latex] \therefore [/latex] Composite correction [latex] \begin{aligned} C &=-0.0785 d^{2}+0.0112 d^{2} \\ &=-0.0673 d^{2} \end{aligned}[/latex] where d is in km, C is in m. [latex] \Rightarrow \quad C=0.0673 \times 1^{2}=0.0673 \mathrm{m}[/latex]

question: Question 65 In a leveling work, sum of the Back Sight (B.S.) and Fore Sight (F.S.) have been found to be 3.085 m and 5.645 m respectively. If the Reduced Level (R.L.) of the starting station is 100.000 m, the R.L. (in m) of the last station is _______.
solution: Using Rise and Fall method [latex] \begin{aligned} \Sigma F S, &>\Sigma B . S \\ \therefore \text { Fall }&=\Sigma F . S,-\Sigma B . S .=R . L, \text { of first }\\ &\text{station - R.L, of last station}\\ &=5.645-3.085=2.56 \mathrm{m}\\ R.L.\text{ (last station) }&= R.L.\text{ (firet station) - Fall}\\ &=100-2.56=97.44 \mathrm{m} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 66 In a region with magnetic declination of [latex]2^{\circ}E[/latex] , the magnetic Force Bearing (FB) of a line AB was measured as [latex]N79^{\circ}{50}'E[/latex] . There was local attraction at A. To determine the correct magnetic bearing to the line, a point O was selected at which there was no local attraction. The magnetic FB of line AO and OA were observed to be [latex]S 52^{\circ}{40}'E[/latex] and [latex]N 50^{\circ}{20}'W[/latex] respectively. What is the true FB of line AB?
solution: Magnetic Declination, [latex]\delta=2^{\circ} \mathrm{E} [/latex] Magnetic FB of AB [latex]=\mathrm{N} 79^{\circ} 50'E[/latex] To find local atraction at station A As station O is free from local attraction Heance FB of OA will be correct Correct FB of OA [latex]= N 50^{\circ}20^{\circ}W=309^{\circ}40^{\circ}[/latex] [latex] \therefore [/latex] Correct BB of [latex]OA = 120^{\circ}40^{\circ}[/latex] [latex] \because[/latex] Obserbed FB of AO = Observed BB of OA [latex] =120^{\circ}40^{\circ}[/latex] [latex] 127^{\circ}20^{\circ}[/latex] Error [latex]= MB = TB =127^{\circ}20^{\circ}=120^{\circ}40^{\circ}[/latex] [latex] ==2^{\circ}20^{\circ}[/latex] Correction [latex]=+2^{\circ}20^{\circ}[/latex] Local attraction at station A [latex] =+2^{\circ}20^{\circ}=2^{\circ}20^{\circ}E[/latex] [latex] \therefore [/latex] Magnetic FB of [latex]AB=N76^{\circ}50^{\circ}E[/latex] [latex] \delta = 2^{\circ}E[/latex] and local attraction [latex]=2^{\circ}20^{\circ}E[/latex] [latex] \therefore[/latex] TB of FB of AB [latex]= 70^{\circ}50^{\circ}+2^{\circ}20^{\circ}+2^{\circ}[/latex] [latex] =N84^{\circ}10^{\prime}E[/latex]

question: Question 67 In a survey work, three independent angle, X, Y and Z were observed with weight [latex]W_{X},W_{Y},W_{Z}[/latex] respectively. The weight of the sum of angles X, Y and Z is given by:
Question 68 In a closed loop traverse of 1 km total length, the closing errors in departure and latitude are 0.3 m and 0.4m, respectively. The relative precision of this traverse will be:
solution: Relative precision [latex]=\frac{1}{p / e} [/latex] where p= Perimeter of traverse e= Closing error Closing error, [latex]e=\sqrt{0.3^{2}+0.4^{2}}=0.5 \mathrm{m} [/latex] Relative precision [latex]=\frac{1}{\frac{1000}{0.5}}=\frac{1}{2000}[/latex]

question: Question 70 The chainage of the intersection point of two straights is 1585.60 m and the angle of intersection is [latex]140^{\circ}[/latex]. If the radius of a circular curve is 600.00 m, the tangent distance (in m) and length of the curve (in m), respectively are

question: Question 71 A tachometer was placed at point P to estimate the horizontal distances PQ and PR. The corresponding stadia intercepts with the telescope kept horizontal, are 0.320 m and 0.210 m, respectively. The [latex]\angle QPR[/latex] is measured to be [latex]61^{\circ}{30}'{30}''[/latex]. If the stadia multiplication constant=100 and stadia addition constant=0.10 m, the horizontal distance (in m) between the points Q and R is ________
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} P Q &=k s+C \\ &=100(0.32)+0.1=32.1 \mathrm{m} \\ P R &=k s+C \\ &=100(0.21)+0.1=21.1 \mathrm{m} \end{aligned}[/latex] Applying the cosine rule [latex] \begin{array}{l} Q R=\sqrt{P Q^{2}+P R^{2}-2(P Q)(P R) \cos \theta} \\ \text { Where, } \theta=61^{\circ} 30^{\prime} 30^{\prime \prime}=61.508^{\circ} \\ =\sqrt{1030,41+445.21-2(32,1)(21,1) \cos 61.508^{\circ}} \\ =\sqrt{1030.41+445.21-646.2}=28.8 \mathrm{m} \end{array}[/latex]

question:
Question 76 A theodolite is set up at station A and a 3 m long staff is held vertically at station B. The depression
angle reading at 2.5 m marking on the staffis 6[latex]^{\circ}[/latex]10'. The horizontal distance between A and B is
2200 m. Height of instrument at station A is 1.1 m and R.L. of A is 880.88 m. Apply the curvature
and refraction correction, and determine the R.L. of B (in m). __________
solution: RL of [latex]\mathrm{A}=880.88 \mathrm{m} [/latex] RL of plane of collimation [latex] =880.88+1.1=881.98 \mathrm{m}[/latex] [latex] \begin{aligned} \frac{B B^{\prime \prime}}{C B^{\prime}} &=\tan 6^{\circ} 10^{\prime} \\ B^{\prime} B^{\prime} &=2200 \mathrm{m} \times \tan 6^{\circ} 10^{\prime} \\ &=237.701 \mathrm{m}\\ \text{RL of }B&=R L\text{ of Ine of sight }-B B^{\prime \prime} \\ &=881.98-237.701-(25-0.3257) \\ &=642.105 \mathrm{m} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 77 Following bearings are observed while traversing with a compass. After applying the correction due to local attraction, the corrected fore bearing of line BC will be:
solution: The difference between back bearing and fore bearing of line DE [latex] =258^{\circ} 30^{\circ}-78^{\circ} 30^{\circ}=180^{\circ} [/latex] [latex] \therefore [/latex] Station D and E are free from local attraction Fore bearing of line [latex] E A=216^{\circ} 30^{\circ} [/latex] [latex] \therefore [/latex] Correct back bearing of line EA [latex] \begin{array}{c} =216^{\circ} 30^{\circ}-180^{\circ}=36^{\circ} 30^{\circ}\\ \therefore \text{ Error at } A=31^{\circ} 45^{\circ}-36^{\circ} 30^{\circ} \\ =-4^{\circ} 45^{\circ} \end{array}[/latex] Hence correction at [latex] A=+4^{\circ} 45[/latex] [latex] \therefore [/latex] Correct fore bearing of line AB [latex] \begin{array}{l} =126^{\circ} 45^{\prime}+4^{\circ} 45^{\prime} \\ =131^{\circ} 30^{\prime} \end{array}[/latex] Correct back bearing of AB [latex] \begin{array}{l} =131^{\circ} 30+180^{\circ} \\ =311^{\circ} 30^{\prime} \end{array}[/latex] [latex] \therefore [/latex] Error at [latex]B=-3^{\circ} 30^{\circ} [/latex] Correction at [latex]\mathrm{B}=+3^{\circ} 30^{\circ} [/latex] Hence correct bearing of BC [latex] \begin{array}{l} =45^{\circ} 15^{\prime}+3^{\circ} 30^{\prime} \\ =48^{\circ} 45^{\prime} \end{array}[/latex]

question:
Question 78 The latitude and departure of a line AB are +78 m and -45.1 m, respectively. The whole circle
bearing of the line AB is:
solution: since the latitude of line is positive and departure is negative, the line lies in the second quadrant. [latex] \begin{aligned} \therefore \quad l \cos \theta &=78 \\ l \sin \theta &=-45.1 \\ \Rightarrow \quad \tan \theta &=-0.578 \\ \quad \theta&=-30^{\circ}\\ \therefore W C B \text{ of } A B&=360^{\circ}-30^{\circ} \\ &=380^{\circ} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 79 The horizontal distance between two stations P and Q is 100 m. The vertical angles from P and Q
to the top of a vertical tower at T are 3[latex]^{\circ}[/latex] and 5[latex]^{\circ}[/latex] above horizontal, respectively. The vertical angles from P and Q to the base of the tower are 0.1[latex]^{\circ}[/latex] and 0.5[latex]^{\circ}[/latex] below horizontal, respectively. Stations P,
Q and the tower are in the same vertical plane with P and Q being on the same side of T. Neglecting
earth's curvature and atmospheric refraction, the height (in m) of the tower is
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} x(\tan 3+\tan 0.1)&=(x-100)\left(\tan 5^{\circ}+\tan 0.5^{\circ}\right) \\ \Rightarrow \quad x&=228.758 \end{aligned}[/latex] [latex] \begin{aligned} \text { Height of tower } &=228.758\left(\tan 3^{\circ}+\tan 0.1^{\circ}\right) \\ &=12.387 \mathrm{m} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 80 Which of the following errors can be eliminated by reciprocal measurements in differential leveling? I Error due to earth's curvature II Error due to atmospheric refraction
solution:
Reciprocal levelling eliminates the errors due to
(i) Error in instrument adjustment.
(ii) Combined effect of earth's curvature and the refraction of the atmosphere.
(iii) Variation in the average refraction.

question: Question 81 The observations from a closed loop traverse around an obstacle are What is the value of the missing measurement (rounded off to the nearest 10 mm)?
solution: In a closed loop travers, the algebraic sum of all the latitudes should be equal to zeroi.e., [latex]\Sigma.=0 [/latex] [latex] \begin{aligned} \Rightarrow\quad L \cos 33.7500^{\circ}&+300 \cos 86.3847^{\circ} \\ +354.524 \cos &169.3819^{\circ}+450 \\ \cos 243.900^{\circ}&+268 \cos 317.5^{\circ}=0 \\ \Rightarrow\quad L \cos 33.75^{\circ} &=329.9166 \\ \Rightarrow\quad L &=396.79 \mathrm{m} \end{aligned}[/latex]

Question 83 A bench mark has been established at the soffit of an ornamental arch at the
known elevation of 100.0 m above mean sea level. The back sight used to establish
height of instrument is a inverted staffreading of 2.105m. A forward sight reading
with normally held staff of 1.105m is taken on a recently constructed plinth. The
elevation of the plinth is
solution: Height of instrument =BM + Back sight since, the staff is inverted, the back sight will be negative. [latex] \therefore [/latex] Height of instrument [latex] =100+(-2.105)=97.897 m[/latex] Elevation of plinth = Height of instrument-Fore sight [latex] =97.895-1.105=96.790 \mathrm{m}[/latex]

question: Question 84 The local mean time at a place located in longitude 90[latex]^{\circ}[/latex]40' E when the standard time is 6 hours and 30 minutes and the standard meridian is 82[latex]^{\circ}[/latex]30' E is
solution: Difference between standard meridian and the longitude of the given [latex] \text { place }=90^{\circ} 40^{\circ} \mathrm{E}-82^{\circ} 30^{\circ} \mathrm{E}=8^{\circ} 10^{\prime}[/latex] The longitude of the given place is more than the standard meridian. Hence the local mean time of the given place will be ahead of the standard time. [latex] 8^{\circ}=\frac{8}{15} \text { hours }[/latex] =0 hours and 32 minutes and 0 seconds [latex] 10^{\prime}=\frac{10}{15} \text { minutes }[/latex] =0 hours and 0 minutes and 40 seconds Time for a difference of [latex] 8^{\circ} 10^{\prime}=32[/latex] minutes and 40 seconds Local mean time = standard time +32 minutes and 40 seconds [latex] \begin{aligned} =& 6 \text { hours and } 30 \text { minutes } \\ &+32 \text { minutes and } 40 \text { seconds } \\ =& 7 \text { hours, } 02 \text { minutes and } 40 \text{seconds} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 85 Determine the correctness or otherwise of the following Assertion[a] and the Reason[r]: Assertion[a]: Curvature correction must be applied when the sights are long. Reason[r]: Line of collimation is not a level line but is tangential to the level line.
solution: For Long sight curvature correction must be applied because due to curvature of earth, lines of collimation differs from the level line, It is tengential to level lines.

options.A: both [a] and [r] are true and [r] is the correct explanation of [a]
options.B: both [a] and [r] are true but [r] is not a correct explanation of [a]

question:
Question 86 The magnetic bearing of a line AB was [latex]N\; 59^{\circ} {30}' \; W[/latex]
 in the year 1967, when the
declination was [latex]4^{\circ}10' E[/latex]. If the present declination is [latex]3^{\circ}\; W[/latex], the whole circle bearing of the line is
solution: True Bearing of [latex] \begin{aligned} \mathrm{AB}&=\text { Magnetic bearing of } \mathrm{AB}\\ &- \text{ Magnetic declination}\\ &=\mathrm{N} 59^{\circ} 30 \mathrm{W}-4^{\circ} 10^{\prime} \\ &=\mathrm{N} 55^{\circ} 20 \mathrm{W} \end{aligned}[/latex] Present Magnetic bearing of [latex] \begin{aligned} \mathrm{AB}&=\text { True bearing } \mathrm{AB}\\ &-\text{ Magnetic declination}\\ &=\mathrm{N} 55^{\circ} 20 \mathrm{W}-3^{\circ} \\ &=\mathrm{N} 52^{\circ} 20 \mathrm{W} \end{aligned}[/latex] Whole circle bearing of [latex] A B=360^{\circ}-52^{\circ} 20^{\prime}=307^{\circ} 40^{\prime}[/latex]

Question 88 A light house of 120 m height is just visible above the horizon from a ship. The
correct distance (m) between the ship and the light house considering combined
correction for curvature and refraction, is
solution: Correction due to curvature, [latex] C_{c}=-0.0785 d^{2}[/latex] Correction due to refraction, [latex] C_{r}=+0.0112 d^{2}[/latex] [latex] \therefore [/latex] Composte correction. [latex] \begin{aligned} C &=-0.0785 d^{2}+0.0112 d^{2} \\ &=-0.0673 \phi^{2} \end{aligned}[/latex] where C is in metres and d is in Klometers [latex] \begin{aligned} \text{Here}\quad C&=120 \mathrm{m}, d=?\\ 120&=0.0673 \times 0^{2} \\ \Rightarrow d&=\sqrt{1783.06} \\ \Rightarrow d&=42208 \times 1000 \\ \Rightarrow d&=4206 \mathrm{m} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 89 A road is provided with a horizontal circular curve having deflection angle of 55[latex]^{\circ}[/latex] 
and centre line radius of 250 m. A transition curve is to be provided at each end
of the circular curve of such a length that the rate of gain of radial acceleration
is 0.3 [latex]m/s^{3}[/latex] at a speed of 50 km per hour. Length of the transition curve required at each of the ends is
solution: If [latex]\alpha[/latex] is the rate of change of radial acceleration, the radial acceleration (a) attained during the time the vehicle passes over the transition curve is given by [latex] a=\alpha t=\alpha \times \frac{L}{V}[/latex] Radial acceleration, [latex] \begin{aligned} a&=\frac{v^{2}}{R} \\ \therefore \quad \alpha \times \frac{L}{V}&=\frac{v^{2}}{R} \\ \Rightarrow \quad L&=\frac{V^{3}}{\alpha R} \\ \therefore \quad L&=\frac{\left(\frac{50 \times 1000}{60 \times 60}\right)^{3}}{0.3 \times 250}\\ \Rightarrow \quad L&=35.73 \mathrm{m} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 90 The focal length of the object glass of a tacheometer is 200 mm, the distance
between the vertical axis of the tacheometer and the optical centre of the object
glass is 100 mm and the spacing between the upper and lower line of the diagram
axis is 4 mm. With the line of collimation perfectly horizontal, the staff intercepts
are 1 m (top), 2m (middle), and 3 m (bottom). The horizontal distance (m)
between the staff and the instrument station is
solution: The horizontal distance (D) between the vertical axis and staff may be given as [latex] \begin{aligned} D &=u+d \\ \text { But } u &=\left(\frac{f}{i}\right) s+f \\ D &=\left(\frac{f}{i}\right) s+f+d \\ &=\left(\frac{200}{4}\right) \times(3-1)+\frac{200}{1000}+\frac{100}{1000} \\ &=100+0.3=100.3 m \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 91 The lengths and bearing of a closed traverse PQRSP are given below. The missing length and bearing, respectively of the line SP are
solution: For a closed traverse sum of latitutes and departures should be zero respectively l.e. [latex] \begin{array}{l} \sum L=0\\ 200 \cos 0^{\circ}+1000 \cos 45^{\circ}+907 \cos 180^{\circ} \\ +L\cos \theta=0 \quad\ldots(i)\\ L\cos \theta=-0.10678 \\ 2D=0 \\ 200 \sin \theta^{2}+1000 \sin 45^{\circ}+907 \sin 180^{\circ} \\ +L\sin \theta=0 \\ L \sin \theta = -707.10678 \quad\ldots(ii) \end{array}[/latex] Dividing (i) by (ii) we get [latex] \tan \theta = 6622.09[/latex] [latex] \theta = 270^{\circ}[/latex] [latex] \therefore L = \frac{-707.10678}{\sin 270^{\circ}}=707.10678m[/latex]

question:
Question 92 The plan of a survey plotted to a scale of 10 m to 1 cm is reduced in such a way
that a line originally 10 cm long now measures 9 cm. The area of the reduced plan
is measured as 81 [latex]cm^{2}[/latex]. The actual area ([latex]m^{2}[/latex]) of the survey is
solution: Shrinking factor [latex]= \frac{9}{10}=0.9[/latex] Reduced plan area [latex]=(\text { Shrinkage factor })^{2} [/latex] [latex] \times [/latex] Actual plan area [latex] \Rightarrow \quad 81=(0.9)^{2} \times [/latex] Actual plan area [latex] \Rightarrow [/latex] Actual plan area [latex]=100 \mathrm{cm}^{2} [/latex] [latex] \therefore \quad [/latex] Actual area of survey in [latex] \mathrm{m}^{2} [/latex] [latex] \begin{aligned} &=100 \times(10)^{2} \\ &=10000 \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 93 The type of surveying in which the curvature of the earth is taken into account
is called
solution:
Geodetic surveying is that type of surveying in which the shape of the earth is taken into account.
Geodetic surveying involves spherical
trigonometry.

question: Question 94 The magnetic bearing of a line AB is S 45[latex]^{\circ}[/latex] E and the declination is 5[latex]^{\circ}[/latex] West. The true bearing of the line AB is
solution: The bearng of AB, [latex](\alpha)[/latex] = MB of AB + Magnetic declination [latex] =45^{\circ}+5^{\circ}=S\; 50^{\circ} \mathrm{E}[/latex]

question:
Question 95 Two straight lines intersect at an angle of 60[latex]^{\circ}[/latex]. The radius of a curve joining the two straight lines is 600 m. The length of long chord and mid-ordinate in metres
of the curve are
solution: Length of long chord, [latex] \begin{aligned} T_{1} T_{2} &=2 R \sin (\Delta / 2) \\ &=2 \times 600 \times \sin (60 / 2) \\ &=600 \mathrm{m} \quad\left(\because \Delta=60^{\circ}\right) \end{aligned}[/latex] Length of mid-ordinate, [latex] \begin{aligned} M &=R[1-\cos (\Delta / 2)] \\ &=600[1-\cos (60 / 2)] \\ &=600 \times 0.134=80.4 \mathrm{m} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 96 The following measurements were made during testing a levelling instrument. [latex]P_{1}[/latex]
 is close to P and [latex]Q_{1}[/latex] is close to Q . If the reduced level of station P is 100.000 m, the reduced level of station Q is
solution: Diference of staff reading at [latex]P_{1}[/latex] and Q When instrument is at P + Difference of staff [latex] n=\frac{\text{readings at }P_{1} \text{ and }Q_{1}\text{ when instrument is at Q }}{2}[/latex] [latex] \Rightarrow h=\frac{(2.800-1.700)+(2.700-1.800)}{2} [/latex] [latex] \Rightarrow h=1 [/latex] [latex] \therefore [/latex] Reduced level of station, Q= Reduced level of P+h [latex] =100.000+1=101.000 \mathrm{m}[/latex]

question:
Question 97 The following table gives data of consecutive coordinates in respect of a closed
theodolite traverse PQRSP. The magnitude and direction of error of closure in whole circle bearing are.
solution: [latex]\Delta L=400.75+100.25-199.0-300.0=2 [/latex] [latex] \Delta D=-300.5+199.25+299.75^{*}-200.5=-2 [/latex] [* This value is given as 399.75 in the original question paper Which is incorrect] [latex] \therefore [/latex]Error of closure. [latex] \begin{aligned} e &=\sqrt{(\Delta L)^{2}+(\Delta D)^{2}} \\ &=\sqrt{(2)^{2}+(-2)^{2}}=2.82 \mathrm{m}\\ \therefore \quad \tan \theta&=\frac{\Delta D}{\Delta L} \\ \Rightarrow \quad \theta&=\tan ^{-1}\left(\frac{-2}{2}\right) \\ \Rightarrow \quad \theta&=-45^{\circ} \\ \text{or}\quad \theta&=360-45=315^{\circ} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 98 The plan of a map was photo copied to a reduced size such that a line originally
100 mm, measures 90 mm. The original scale of the plan was 1:1000. The revised scale is
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \text { Reduction factor }&=\frac{90}{100}=0.9 \\ \text { Revised scale }&=\text { Original scale }\\ &\times \text { Reduction factor }\\ =\frac{1}{1000} \times 0.9&=\frac{1}{1000 / 0.9}=\frac{1}{1111} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 99 During a levelling work along a falling gradient using a Dumpy level and a Staff
of 3 m length, following successive readings were taken :
1.785,2.935,0.360,1.320. What will be the correct order of booking these four
readings in a level book ? (BS : Back Sight, IS : Intermediate Sight, FS : Fore Sight)
solution: The first reading is always BS. The second reading is foresight because the instrument has been shifted after this reading which is evident from the low value of third reading. Since the instrument has been shifted the third reading is backlight again. Successively the fourth reading is foresight.

question: Question 100 In the figure given below, the length PQ (WCB : 30[latex]^{\circ}[/latex]) and QR (WCB : 45[latex]^{\circ}[/latex]) respectively up to three places of decimal are
solution: Let, length of PQ and QR are [latex]L_{1}[/latex] and [latex]L_{2} [/latex] respectively. From P, coordiantes of [latex]Q =(100+L_{1}\cos 30^{\circ},200 \left.+L_{1} \sin 30^{\circ}\right) [/latex] From R, coordinates of [latex]Q=\left(1000-L_{2},\cos 45^{\circ},\right. \left.1000-L_{9} \sin 45^{\circ}\right) [/latex] But, [latex] 100 + L_{1} \cos 30^{\circ} = 100-L_{2}\cos45^{\circ}[/latex] [latex] \Rightarrow \frac{\sqrt{3}}{2} L_{1}+\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}} L_{9}=900 \;\;\;...(i)[/latex] and [latex]200+L_{1} \sin 30^{n}=1000-L_{2} \sin 46^{\prime} [/latex] [latex] \Rightarrow \frac{1}{2} L_{1}+\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}} L_{9}=800 \;\;\; ...(ii)[/latex] Solving (i) and (ii) we get [latex] L_{1}=273.206 \mathrm{m}\text{ and }\mathrm{L}_{2}=936.166 \mathrm{m}[/latex]

question:
Question 101 Consider the following figure, which is an extract from a contour map (scale
=1:20,000) of an area. An alignment of a road at a ruling gradient of 4% is to be
fixed from the point O and beyond. What should be the radius of the arc with
O as the center to get the point of alignment on the next contour on the map ?
solution: The contour interval =20 m For 4% gradient, the length needed from one contour to another [latex] =\frac{20}{0.04}=500 \mathrm{m}[/latex] [latex] \therefore[/latex] Radius of arc [latex]=\frac{500 \times 100}{20000}=2.5 \mathrm{cm}[/latex]

question:
Question 102 A Bench Marck (BM) with Reduced Level (RL) = 155.305 m has been established
at the floor of a room. It is required to find out the RL of the underside of root
(R) of the room using Spirit Levelling. The Back Sight (BS) to the BM has been
observed as 1.500 m whereas the Fore Sight (FS) to R has been observed as 0.575
m (Shaff held inverted). The RL(m) of R will be
solution: Height of instrument [latex] \begin{aligned} &=\mathrm{RL} \text { of bench mark }+\mathrm{BS} \\ &=155.305+1.500 \\ &=156.805 \mathrm{m} \end{aligned}[/latex] Now, the staff is held inverted and the foresight (FS) is 0.575m [latex] \begin{aligned} \therefore \quad \text{ RL of R}&=\text{ Height of instrument }+ FS \\ &=156.805+0.575 \\ &=157.380 \mathrm{m} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 103 The observed magnetic bearing of a line OE was found to be 185[latex]^{\circ}[/latex]. It was later discovered that station O had a local attraction of +1.5[latex]^{\circ}[/latex].
The true bearing of the line OE, considering a magnetic declination of 3.5[latex]^{\circ}[/latex]E shall be
solution: Observed magnetic bearing of [latex]\mathrm{OE}=185^{\circ} [/latex] Local attraction at [latex]0=+1.5^{\circ} [/latex] Corrected magnetic bearing of [latex] O E=185^{\circ}-1.5^{\circ}=183.6^{\circ} [/latex] [latex] \therefore [/latex] True bearing of OE = Corrected magnetic declination of OE + Magnetic declination [latex] =103.6^{\circ}+3.5^{\circ}=187^{\circ}[/latex]
